subskills.name: Open Response Speaking and Writing
subskills.description: Giving your own spoken or written response
subskills.content:
Read simple academic texts. Try to:

  • understand the writer's purpose
  • notice facts and opinions
  • notice the structure of a paragraph (e.g. the topic sentence, body sentences, concluding or bridge sentence to the next paragraph)
  • pay attention to different linking words used in the text
  • notice examples and their relation to the idea they support
  • summarise information from the text

Listen to simple presentations or lectures.

  • Pay attention to the main ideas and supporting details.
  • Taking notes while listening.
  • Notice opinions.
  • Summarise the information from the presentation or lecture.

Write simple structured essays.

Listen to or watch a presentation or lecture. Try to:

  • find key details
  • take notes while listening or watching
  • guess the speakers' opinions
  • describe the conclusions
  • summarise it

Practice talking about a graph, chart or process. Work on:

  • understanding numerical values in charts and graphs
  • summarising the main message

subskills.name: Reproducing Spoken and Written Language
subskills.description: Repeating or copying spoken or written information
subskills.content:
Read linguistically complex academic texts. Try to:

  • infer the author's attitude
  • follow the sequence of events or arguments
  • identify key information and vocabulary
  • identify different types of supporting details
  • understand idioms and non-standard language

Listen to authentic materials on complex and unfamiliar topics and try to notice cohesive devices used by the speakers.

subskills.name: Extended Writing
subskills.content:
Improve your skills by reading academic texts on familiar topics. Practice noticing:

  • facts and opinions
  • supporting details from the main points in the text

Listen to presentations, lectures, or discussions in your field of specialisation. Focus on:

  • identifying the main reasons for and against an argument or idea in a discussion
  • the structure of different types of presentations
  • taking notes while listening

Practice writing a text clearly signalling main points and supporting ideas. Work on:

  • writing suitable introductions to a simple academic essay
  • presenting additional ideas using a range of linking words and phrases
  • contrasting two ideas using appropriate linking words

subskills.name: Short Writing
subskills.content: Work on understanding the details of long complex texts in your field.

subskills.name: Extended Speaking
subskills.content:
Work with a friend. Practice talking about graphs, charts or a process.

  • Explain the key information.
  • Describe a process.

Listen to simple recorded presentations, podcasts, or watch videos and TV programmes. Try to:

  • find important details
  • work out the speaker's opinions
  • notice the speaker's feelings and attitude

subskills.name: Short Speaking
subskills.content:
Listen to authentic materials on complex and unfamiliar topics. Try to notice cohesive devices used by the speakers.

Read linguistically complex academic texts and try to:

  • infer the author's attitude
  • understand idioms and non-standard language

subskills.name: Multiple-skills Comprehension
subskills.description: Using more than one skill (eg listening to a clip and then giving a spoken response)
subskills.content:
Listen to linguistically complex presentations, lectures or discussions and work on:

  • identifying the speakers' point of view
  • identifying the main points
  • inferring opinions
  • identifying details supporting a point of view
  • summarising the information

Read linguistically complex academic texts. Work on:

  • following the sequence of events or arguments
  • writing a clear summary of the text

subskills.name: Single-skill Comprehension
subskills.content:
You have achieved a very high score.

To maintain your level of proficiency, you could continue to:

  • read linguistically complex academic, factual and literally texts or listen to presentations, podcasts or lectures on abstract and complex topics outside your field of interest

Work on:

  • understanding the texts and recognising subtle distinctions of style
  • understanding highly colloquial language
  • evaluate the text
